heading: short week = slow trading
subheading: a lackluster day on wall street: the nasdaq takes a breather after an extended winning streak, and the dow is off 94.
author: reuters
text: stocks fell tuesday as investors took money off the table and prepared for the countdown to thanksgiving. based on early and unofficial data, the dow jones industrial average finished with a loss of 93.89 points, or 0.85 percent, at 10,995.63.the technology-laced nasdaq composite index slid 49.69 points, or 1.46 percent, to 3,342.87, a day after it had zipped to its 14th record close in 17 sessions. the nasdaq earlier in the day had rallied to 3,411, surpassing monday's record close of 3,392, but profit-taking got the best of it.the trading week will be shortened by the thanksgiving day holiday."today is crucial because tomorrow is getaway day," said peter cardillo, director of research at westfalia investments.a batch of economic reports will be released wednesday. but none of them are expected to have a major impact on the market.weekly us jobless claims numbers -- usually released on thursday, the conference board's october help-wanted advertising index, and the final university of michigan consumer sentiment index for november, will be issued on wednesday. on friday, personal income and spending data are due.the s&p 500 index fell 16.24 points, or 1.14 percent, to 1,404.70.in the broader market, declining stocks swamped advances 2,190 to 902 on active volume of 919.6 million shares on the new york stock exchange.in the bond market, the 30-year us treasury bond slipped 2/32 and the yield held at monday's close of 6.19 percent."i think a lot of market players are away this week and during these quiet weeks, more profit-taking than buying seems to take place," said peggy farley, chief executive of ascent/meredith asset management. "i don't see any macro events that would drive the market."in company news, drug company pfizer (pfe) filed a new complaint against warner-lambert (wla), claiming the company broke the terms of a contract to keep it at bay while negotiating a merger with american home products (ahp).warner-lambert was down 1 1/16 at 88 1/2; american home was down 1 3/8 at 52 3/8; and pfizer was up 13/16 at 35 11/16.exxon (xon) and mobil (mob) dipped on a report the companies have offered to divest 15 percent of their nationwide gasoline-station network to gain us federal trade commission approval for their $81.02 billion merger.exxon, another dow component, skidded 1 3/16 to 78 1/16 and mobil slid 1 7/8 to 102.a slew of companies made their public debut. among the hottest deals, digital impact, which offers internet direct marketing services to companies, surged 40 1/2 to 55 1/2.opentv, a provider of software for digital interactive television, rocketed up 42 3/4 to 62 3/4.copyright
